competencies.name: Demonstrates Ethical Practice
competencies.definition: Understands and consistently applies coaching ethics and standards of coaching

sub_competencies.text: Demonstrates personal integrity and honesty in interactions with clients, sponsors and relevant stakeholders
Is sensitive to clients’ identity, environment, experiences, values and beliefs 1.03. Uses language appropriate and respectful to clients, sponsors and relevant
Abides by the ICF Code of Ethics and upholds the ICF Core Values
Maintains confidentiality with client information per stakeholder agreements and pertinent laws
Maintains the distinctions between coaching, consulting, psychotherapy and other support professions
Refers clients to other support professionals, as appropriate

competencies.name: Embodies a Coaching Mindset
competencies.definition: Engages in ongoing personal and professional learning and development as a coach. Works with coaching supervisors or mentor coaches as needed. Develops and maintains a mindset that is open, curious, flexible and client -centered.

sub_competencies.text: Acknowledges that clients are responsible for their own choices
Engages in ongoing learning and development as a coach, including remaining aware of current coaching best practices and use of technology
Develops an ongoing reflective practice to enhance one’s coaching
Remains aware of and open to the influence of biases, context and culture
Uses awareness of self and one’s intuition to benefit clients
Develops and maintains the ability to manage one’s emotions
Maintains emotional, physical, and mental well -being in preparation for,
Seeks help from outside sources when necessary
Nurtures openness and curiosity in oneself, the client, and the coaching process.
Remains aware of the influence of one’s thoughts and behaviors on the client and others

competencies.name: Establishes and Maintains Agreements
competencies.definition: Partners with the client and relevant stakeholders to create clear agreements about the coaching relationship, process, plans and goals. Establishes agreements for the overall coaching engagement as well as those for each coaching session.

sub_competencies.text: Describes one's coaching philosophy and clearly defines what coaching is
Reaches agreement about what is and is not appropriate in the relationship,
Reaches agreement about the guidelines and specific parameters of the
Partners with the client and relevant stakeholders to establish an overall
Partners with the client to determine client-coach compatibility
Partners with the client to identify or reconfirm what they want to
Partners with the client to define what the client believes they need to
Partners with the client to define or reconfirm measures of success for what
Partners with the client to manage the time and focus of the session
Continues coaching in the direction of the client’s desired outcome unless
Partners with the client to close the coaching relationship in a way that respects the client and the coaching experience
Revisits the coaching agreement when necessary to ensure the coaching approach is meeting the client's needs

competencies.name: Cultivates Trust and Safety
competencies.definition: Partners with the client to create a safe, supportive environment that allows the client to share freely. Maintains a relationship of mutual respect and trust.

sub_competencies.text: Seeks to understand the client within their context which may include their identity, environment, experiences, values and beliefs
Demonstrates respect for the client’s identity, perceptions, style and
Acknowledges and respects the client’s unique talents, insights and work in
Shows support, empathy and concern for the client
Acknowledges and supports the client’s expression of feelings, perceptions, concerns, beliefs and suggestions
Demonstrates openness and transparency as a way to display vulnerability

competencies.name: Maintains Presence
competencies.definition: Is fully conscious and present with the client, employing a style that is open, flexible, grounded and confident

sub_competencies.text: Remains focused, observant, empathetic and responsive to the client
Demonstrates curiosity during the coaching process
Remains aware of what is emerging for self and client in the present
Manages one’s emotions to stay present with the client
Demonstrates confidence in working with strong client emotions during the
Is comfortable working in a space of not knowing
Creates or allows space for silence, pause or reflection

competencies.name: Listens Actively
competencies.definition: Focuses on what the client is and is not saying to fully understand what is being communicated in the context of the client systems and to support client self -expression

sub_competencies.text: Considers the client’s context, identity, environment, experiences, values and beliefs to enhance understanding of what the client is communicating
Reflects or summarizes what the client is communicating to ensure clarity
Recognizes and inquires when there is more to what the client is
Notices, acknowledges and explores the client’s emotions, energy shifts, non-verbal cues or other behaviors
Integrates the client’s words, tone of voice and body language to determine the full meaning of what the client is communicating
Notices trends in the client’s behaviors and emotions across sessions to

competencies.name: Evokes Awareness
competencies.definition: Facilitates client insight and learning by using tools and techniques such as powerful questioning, silence, metaphor or analogy

sub_competencies.text: Considers client experience when deciding what might be most useful
Challenges the client as a way to evoke awareness or insight
Asks questions about the client, such as their way of thinking, values, needs,
Asks questions that help the client explore beyond current thinking
Invites the client to share more about their experience in the moment
Notices what is working to enhance client progress
Adjusts the coaching approach in response to the client’s needs
Helps the client identify factors that influence current and future patterns of behavior, thinking or emotion
Invites the client to generate ideas about how they can move forward and what they are willing or able to do
Supports the client in reframing perspectives
Shares observations, knowledge, and feelings, without attachment, that have

competencies.name: Facilitates Client Growth
competencies.definition: Partners with the client to transform learning and insight into action. Promotes client autonomy in the coaching process.

sub_competencies.text: Works with the client to integrate new awareness, insight or learning into
Partners with the client to design goals, actions and accountability
Acknowledges and supports client autonomy in the design of goals, actions
Supports the client in identifying potential results or learning from identified action steps
Invites the client to consider how to move forward, including resources,
Partners with the client to summarize learning and insight within or
Partners with the client to integrate learning and sustain progress throughout the coaching engagement
Acknowledges the client’s progress and successes
Partners with the client to close the session

glossary.Accountability: The responsibility to follow through on commitments and actions agreed upon during the coaching process.
glossary.Agreement: A formal document established between an ICF professional and the client(s)/sponsor(s) that outlines the terms, expectations, and conditions of their coaching relationship. It typically includes details such as the goals of the coaching, the duration and  frequency of sessions, confidentiality policies, payment terms, cancellation policies, and the responsibilities of both the coach and the client.
glossary.Analogy: A comparison between two things that highlights similarities between them, often to explain or clarify a concept, process, or situation.
glossary.Autonomy: The client's ability to make independent decisions and take actions based on their own values and beliefs.
glossary.Beliefs: Personal convictions, assumptions, and interpretations that shape how a client sees themselves, others, and the world.
glossary.Bias: A difference in the perception, interpretation, or judgment —shaped by internalized beliefs, values, preferences, and cultural assumptions — that can result in an inclination for or against an idea, object, group, or individual .
glossary.Body Language: Non-verbal communication through gestures, facial expressions, and posture, which can provide insights into a client's feelings and attitudes.
glossary.Challenges: Thought -provoking interventions offered by the coach to disrupt the client’s habitual patterns, assumptions, or narratives.
glossary.Client: The individual, team, or group member being coached, the coach being coached, mentored, or supervised, or the coach in training.
glossary.Client Systems: The network of relationships and environments that influence the client's life and decisions.
glossary.Coach Supervisor (Coaching Supervisor): An experienced coach who engages in reflective dialogue and a collaborative process with a coach (or group of coaches) for personal, professional, and ethical development and learning.
glossary.Coaching Approach: The specific methods and techniques used by a coach to facilitate client growth and development.
glossary.Coaching Engagement: The structured interaction between an ICF professional and the client(s)/sponsor(s). This engagement encompasses the entire coaching process, including the initial assessment, goal setting, regular coaching sessions, progress tracking, and evaluation of o utcomes. 2025  ICF Core Competenc ies © International Coaching Federation   12
glossary.Coaching Philosophy: The underlying theory, beliefs and principles, that guide a coach's practice and interactions with clients.
glossary.Coaching Relationship: A relationship that is established by the ICF Professional and the Client(s)/Sponsor(s) under an agreement or a contract that defines the responsibilities and expectations of each party.
glossary.Confidentiality: The protection of any information obtained in or around the coaching relationship unless there is a legal reason or requirement, a threat of harm, or written consent to release is given by the client.
glossary.Context: The unique combination of circumstances, experiences, culture, identity, environment, and worldview that shape how a person understands themselves, others, and the world.
glossary.Culture: The shared values, beliefs, language, communication, norms, and practices of a group that help define them as a collective and which influence behavior and decision -making.
glossary.Empathy: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another person.
glossary.Energy Shifts: Changes in a client's emotional or physical energy levels, which can impact their engagement and progress in coaching.
glossary.Environment: The physical and social surroundings that affect a client's experiences and decisions.
glossary.Experiences: The events and interactions that shape a client's perceptions, beliefs and behaviors.
glossary.Grounded: Being stable and centered, often referring to a coach's ability to remain calm and focused during sessions.
glossary.Helping/Support Professions: Fields such as counseling, therapy, and social work that provide assistance and support to individuals, sometimes overlapping with coaching practices.
glossary.Identity: The client's sense of self, including their values, beliefs, cultural background, roles, lived experiences, personality, and the ways they see and define themselves in the world.
glossary.Insights: New understandings or realizations that emerge during the coaching process, leading to personal growth.
glossary.Knowledge: Information or skills, gained through study, observation, practice, or direct experience. 2025  ICF Core Competenc ies © International Coaching Federation   13
glossary.Measure of Success: Criteria used to evaluate the effectiveness and outcomes of the coaching process.
glossary.Mentor Coach: An experienced coach who provides a collaborative learning process (mentor coaching) through which feedback is provided to another coach based on observed or recorded coaching sessions, to further develop their unique coaching style and skills in alignmen t with the ICF Core Competencies.
glossary.Metaphor: A figure of speech in which one thing is described as another, creating an implicit comparison. In coaching, metaphors are used to help clients understand their experiences, feelings, or situations by relating them to more familiar or vivid concepts.
glossary.Observations: The act of noticing and interpreting behaviors and patterns in a client's actions and interactions.
glossary.Partners (with)/Partnering: Coach and client working collaboratively toward a common, client -centered goal which supports, encourages, and honors the client's autonomy in the coaching process.
glossary.Perceptions: The way clients interpret and understand their experiences and surroundings.
glossary.Powerful Questioning: The use of thought -provoking questions to stimulate deeper thinking and reflection in clients.
glossary.Presence: The coach's ability to be fully attentive and engaged with the client during sessions.
glossary.Progress: The advancement or improvement in a client's goals and development through the coaching process.
glossary.Reflective Practice: The process of self -examination and learning from one's experiences to improve coaching skills and effectiveness.
glossary.Reframing Perspective: Supporting the client to see a situation, belief, or experience in a new way, so they can discover new meaning, insight, or possibilities.
glossary.Manage One’s Emotions: The ability to recognize, understand, and navigate one's emotional responses in a healthy and intentional way.
glossary.Session: A period of time when a coach and client have a coaching conversation
glossary.Sponsor: The entity (including its representatives) or individual paying for and/or arranging or defining the coaching services to be provided. This includes those having parental responsibility for minors. 2025  ICF Core Competenc ies © International Coaching Federation   14
glossary.Stakeholder: An individual, usually within an organization, who has an interest in a client’s progress through coaching
glossary.Strong Client Emotion: Intense emotional responses or experiences expressed by the client during a coaching session.
glossary.Style: The unique manner in which a coach interacts with clients and conducts sessions.
glossary.Success: The achievement of goals and positive outcomes through the coaching process.
glossary.Technology: Tools, platforms, and systems used by coaches to enhance the coaching process. This may include digital coaching platforms, apps for self- coaching, videoconferencing tools, and AI systems that facilitate goal tracking, communication, and progress monitori ng
glossary.Value or Values: The principles and standards that guide a person's behavior and decision -making.
glossary.Well -Being: A person's emotional and psychological state of overall health and happiness, encompassing resilience, positive emotions, and effective coping with life's challenges.
glossary.Without Attachment: The practice of engaging in the coaching process without being overly invested in specific outcomes, allowing for flexibility and openness.
glossary.Worldview: The overall perspective from which a person sees and interprets the world, influencing their beliefs, values, and actions.
